sections.text:
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
In the present study rheological behavior of SAE 50w Engine Oil containing TiO2 nanoparticles of 30 nm is empirically investigated. Various samples of nanolubricant were made by adding nanoparticles in 0%, 0.125%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75%, 1% and 1.5% solid volume fractions. Dynamic viscosity of the samples was measured in temperature ranges of 25 to 50◦C and in various shear rates. The results clearly showed that the nano-lubricant as well as the base oil were nonNewtonian fluids behaving as power-law equation. From the values of power law index it was revealed that the nano-lubricant exhibited shear thinning behavior, though in high solid volume fractions it tends to Newtonian behavior. With using viscosity data, a new correlation is proposed in terms of temperature and solid volume fraction which has R-squared values of 0.9751. Margins of deviation for experimental data prediction were less than 1.52%. Nano-lubricant was studied to determine its sensitivity to adding a specific extra amount of nanoparticles. It was revealed by the results that the nano-lubricant is more sensitive to solid volume
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
fraction variations than variations of temperature; the sample with 1% solid volume fraction had the maximum sensitivity at 25◦C.
Keywords: Nano-lubricants, Non-Newtonian, nanofluid, New correlation, dynamic viscosity

IP T

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since last decade, numerous studied have been conducted on the nanofluids and the coefficient of thermal conductivity [1–6] as well as viscosity [7–9] of nanofluids to discover the effects of dispersed nanoparticles on improving of heat transfer characteristics of fluids that are used in engineering application. Finding the optimum conditions of nanofluids in terms of volume fraction and temperature of nanoparticles is the biggest challenge for the scientists that study this subject. It is proved in some researches that thermal conductivity of nanofluids is improved so that they are capable of reducing the temperature of every types of heat exchangers [10,11]. It was showed that increasing of TiO2 nanoparticles loading in water would result in viscosity enhancement while temperature has the negative effect on viscosity, TiO2/water nanofluid was found to have shear thickening behavior [12]. Al2O3 nanoparticles have unfavorable effects on turbine oil because of unevenness of heat transfer and pressure drop [13]. in order to make a good prediction viscosity and thermal conductivity behaviors, moreover to artificial neural network modeling [14–16], experimental correlations are proposed in some articles obtained from mathematical modeling and experimental approaches. Some correlations for predicting viscosity are presented in Table 1.

Thermal conductivity and viscosity of nanofluids are among the characteristics that have been subjects of interest since last decade. It has been reported that thermal conductivity of nanofluids are enhanced with increasing the solid volume fraction and temperature [31]. Dynamic viscosity is reduced by solid volume fraction increment while it is enhanced as if temperature is decreased [32,33]. From the studies that have been conducted on rheological behavior of nanofluid it can be concluded that nanofluids behave differently as different material is added to them, so presenting a general rule is not possible [34–38]. Viscosity of Ag-heat transfer oil have been studied by Aberoumand et al. [27] and it has been indicated that the base fluid had Newtonian behavior while it changed to non-Newtonian as small amounts of nanoparticles was added. The maximum solid volume fraction was 0.72% and the nano-lubricant was studied at temperatures between 25 and
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
80 ◦ C. There are a few articles in which non-Newtonian fluids are studied. JamalAbad et al. [39] studied on nano oils with 1 to 2 % solid volume fractions of Al2O3, TiO2 and CuO in shear rates of 100 to 1000. The measurements indicated that the fluids are non-Newtonian. Furthermore, by calculating power law indexes it was revealed that the nano fluids exhibited shear thinning behavior.
In the present study, TiO2/SAE50 nano-lubricant is investigated with regard to its rheological behavior. Viscosity of samples of nano-lubricant with volume fractions of 0%, 0.125%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75%, 1% and 1.5% was evaluated at temperatures between 25 and 50 ◦ C and in different shear rates, also dynamic viscosity of the nano-lubricant was predicted by a new correlation which is proposed in this paper for the first time, such a study has never been done before.

sections.heading: 2. Experimentation
sections.text:
In this experiments, TiO2/SAE50 nano-lubricant was prepared in 0%, 0.125%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75%, 1% and 1.5% solid volume fractions and by the use of twostep method. The required weights of TiO2 nanoparticles for each sample were calculated using Eq. 1.
2

TiO SAE

w w
 
 
     
    
       
(1)
In this equation ρ stands for density and w stands for weight of nanoparticles.TiO2 nanoparticles with mean diameter of 30 nm were dispersed in SAE50 oil by a mechanical blender for 3 hours.
For the purpose of eliminating agglomerations of nanoparticles, the samples of nano-lubricant were exposed to ultrasonic waves generated by 1200 W ultrasonic
AC CE
PT
ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
processor which was made by Kimia Nano Danesh (KND) (I.R. Iran). The samples were blended by the ultrasonic processor for 6 hours and at frequency of 20 KHz leading to uniform and homogeneous suspensions of nanofluids. Different samples of TiO2/SAE40 nano-lubricant and TiO2 nano powder are illustrated in Fig. 1.
Fig. 1. Photograph of TiO2 nanoparticles, SAE 50 engine oil and nano-lubricant samples.
Dynamic viscosity of nano-lubricant samples with various solid volume fractions were performed at temperatures between 25 and 50 ◦ C and in shear rates from 666.5 up to 9331 s -1 . Brookfield viscometer made by Brookfield engineering laboratories (USA) were utilized for dynamic viscosity measurements. Some of the measured data are listed in table 2. Accuracy and repeatability of the apparatus were ±1.0% and ±0.2%, respectively. Ethylene Glycol and glycerin were used for calibrating the viscometer at room temperature.

sections.heading: 3. Result and discussion
sections.text:
3.1. The effects of concentration and temperature on dynamic viscosity
Variations of dynamic viscosity of TiO2/SAE 50 versus solid volume fraction are illustrated in Fig. 2. This diagram is drawn for shear rate of 3999 and at different temperatures. As a result of increasing of TiO2 volume fraction in the base oil which is synonymous with increasing of nanoparticles loading, shear stress between fluid layers is enhanced, in other words the layers are less prone to move because of increased inter-layer friction, and therefore viscosity is enhanced. Viscosity enhancement at low temperature is more significant than high temperatures. Basically temperature increment leads to viscosity reduction due to facilitated fluid particles movement. This phenomenon was occurred for TiO2/SAE 50 and it can be clearly seen in this figure.

In Fig. 3, for constant temperature of 40 ◦ C, variations of dynamic viscosity versus solid volume fraction of samples of nano-lubricant in various shear rates are depicted. Viscosity is not affected by shear rate variations in Newtonian fluids. With regard to this figure viscosity of nano-lubricant is considerably changed as a result of shear rate variation in a constant solid volume fraction.

A fluid which follows power-law of Ostwald–de Waele is a generalized
Newtonian fluid that its viscosity is defined as below:
nm  (1)
Apparent viscosity is defined by below equation:
1nm   (2)
In above equations τ represents shear stress, m is consistency index, n stands for
power law index and is shear rate. Newtonian fluids are specified if n is equal to
1, while non-Newtonian fluids are recognized if n not equal to 1. Shear thinning or semi-plastic behavior is occurred when 2 is lower than 1 and if it is higher than 1 then the fluid exhibits shear thickening behavior.
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
In Fig. 4, variations of apparent viscosity versus shear rate are presented for different solid volume fractions and temperatures. According to this figure, apparent viscosity of nano-lubricant samples is reduced as a result of shear rate increment regardless of temperature and solid volume fraction. This decrement signifies shear thinning behavior of nano oil. This can be explained by the fact that high shear rate can remove agglomerations of nanoparticles. Generally, agglomerations increase viscosity thus viscosity would be reduced if they are eliminated.

Diagram of nano oil’s consistency index versus solid volume fraction at different temperatures is depicted in Fig. 6. Regarding to this figure increment of solid volume fraction at low temperatures cause fluctuations of consistency index, but at higher temperatures consistency index is not varied significantly as solid volume fraction increases. Dynamic viscosity of the nanofluid is directly affected by consistency index. At the temperature of 25 ◦ C, consistency index is relatively increased and as its result viscosity is enhanced. As it previously mentioned in Fig. 3, viscosity is significantly enhanced at 25 ◦ C.

3.3. Proposed correlation
In order to calculate dynamic viscosity of TiO2/SAE 50, a novel correlation is proposed in terms of temperature and solid volume fraction, this correlation is presented below:
1.2854 0.1444 0.013802 0.00175nf bf
T T 
  
    (4)
Where φ is solid volume fraction, T is temperature and subscript of nf and bf represent nanofluid and base fluid respectively. R-squared of this correlation was calculated equal to 0.9751. R-Squared value closer to 1 indicates a good fit model based on good data[40]. This correlation predicts relative viscosity of TiO2/SAE50 nano-lubricant with solid volume fractions of 0.125 up to 1.5% and it is convenient for temperatures between 15 and 55 ◦ C. Margins of deviation (MOD) of predicted data were calculated using Eq. 5.

According to this diagram the correlation has predicted experimental data of viscosity with appropriate accuracy as most of data has margins of deviation less than 1%. Maximum MOD of 1.52% belongs to the sample with 0.125% solid volume fraction and it occurred at 25 ◦ C.

In order to compare the proposed correlation with common theoretical models, viscosity data were predicted by Wang et al. [41]، Chen et al. [25]، Lundgren [42] and Brinkman [19] models. As it can be seen in Fig. 10, dynamic viscosity data of TiO2/SAE 50 nano-lubricant are predicted with excellent accordance with experimental data and all points are laid on the bisector line. Theoretical models predictions have an almost acceptable accuracy for samples with solid volume
AC CE
PT ED
M
AN
fractions less than 1.02% but their accuracy are obliterated for high contents of nanoparticles.
As a result of adding nanoparticles to oils, viscosity sensitivity is increased; it means that in case of adding extra amounts of nanoparticles, viscosity would be enhanced more than expected values. Sensitivity of various samples of TiO2/SAE 50 nano-lubricant with different volume fractions to adding 10% extra nanoparticles content were calculated using equation below:
(6)
Sensitivity was calculated for different solid volume fractions and its values are presented in Fig. 11. Regarding to this figure in a specific solid volume fraction regardless of temperature, sensitivity of samples to adding 10% extra nanoparticles is higher at low temperatures. Also at a constant temperature and in different solid volume fractions, samples with high nanoparticles content are significantly more
AC CE
PT
ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
sensitive to adding extra 10% nanoparticles compared to samples with low solid volume fractions. From all of this it can be concluded that maximum sensitivity occurs at highest solid volume fraction and lowest temperature, this is clearly observable in the figure. Also it can be obtained that TiO2/SAE 50 nano-lubricant is more sensitive to solid volume fraction than temperature.
Fig. 11. Sensitivity to temperature and solid volume fraction
4. Conclusion
In this article, rheological behavior of a nano-oil containing TiO2 nanoparticles of 30 nm were empirically studied. Dynamic viscosity of samples with solid volume fractions of 0%, 0.125%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75%, 1% and 1.5% were measured at temperatures between 25 and 50 ◦ C and in shear rate ranges from 666.5 to 9331 s -1 . From the result it was revealed that the base oil and different samples of nano-lubricant were non-Newtonian fluids. By using Ostwald–de Waele equation and calculating its indexes it was indicated that SAE 50 oil exhibits shear thinning behavior. Power law index was enhanced by increment of solid volume fraction which means that nano-lubricant would become Newtonian if solid
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
volume fraction is increased. Consistency index was intensely reduced as a result of temperature increment. According to experimental viscosity data, a novel correlation in terms of solid volume fraction and temperature was proposed for prediction of viscosity data, the correlation had R-squared of 0.9751. The proposed correlation was desirably accurate for predicting experimental data. Sensitivity of nano-lubricant to addition of extra nanoparticles content was evaluated, the results signified that the nano-lubricant is more sensitive to variations of solid volume fraction that variations of temperature.

metadata.abstractText: In the present study rheological behavior of SAE 50w Engine Oil containing TiO2 nanoparticles of 30 nm is empirically investigated. Various samples of nanolubricant were made by adding nanoparticles in 0%, 0.125%, 0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75%, 1% and 1.5% solid volume fractions. Dynamic viscosity of the samples was measured in temperature ranges of 25 to 50◦C and in various shear rates. The results clearly showed that the nano-lubricant as well as the base oil were nonNewtonian fluids behaving as power-law equation. From the values of power law index it was revealed that the nano-lubricant exhibited shear thinning behavior, though in high solid volume fractions it tends to Newtonian behavior. With using viscosity data, a new correlation is proposed in terms of temperature and solid volume fraction which has R-squared values of 0.9751. Margins of deviation for experimental data prediction were less than 1.52%. Nano-lubricant was studied to determine its sensitivity to adding a specific extra amount of nanoparticles. It was revealed by the results that the nano-lubricant is more sensitive to solid volume ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
